Award.AbstractNarration:
Virtual organizations are becoming increasingly important in driving production and innovation. Online production groups have the potential to transform the way that knowledge is produced and disseminated, but are often plagued with coordination problems that exceed those encountered by comparable co-located groups. Coordination is especially challenging for organizations engaged in complex, interdependent tasks typical of science and engineering. These groups often involve large numbers of contributors with tenuous and poorly defined relationships to the virtual organization and each other, who must coordinate to create coherent knowledge artifacts. For example, the volunteer editors who write Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, must produce a collection of articles that are complete, accurate, coherent and readable. To solve these coordination challenges groups use a variety of mechanisms, including market bidding, standardization, strong leadership, and direct communication.

This project seeks to understand the effectiveness of particular coordination mechanisms for solving the coordination challenges faced by online production groups. The research will examine how online production groups use a variety of coordination mechanisms to solve problems of task assignment, temporal dependencies and fit between work outputs. It will examine the conditions under which these coordination mechanisms are successful in existing online knowledge production communities, such as Wikipedia and the thousands of other wikis that use a similar infrastructure. The effectiveness of these coordination mechanisms will then be tested in controlled online experiments, using artificial production groups recruited to synthesize information into coherent knowledge. This research extends theories of coordination to large scale virtual organizations, providing a greater understanding of how large groups of individuals can effectively work together online. The results will help virtual organizations to more effectively coordinate, engage participants in tasks that are important to the group, and coherently synthesize knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Virtual organizations are becoming increasingly important in driving production and innovation in science, engineering and knowledge production. For example, virtual organizations have created the largest encyclopedia in the world (Wikipedia) and the software that drives the internet (Linux, Apache). However, our understanding of what makes these organizations successful is limited. One possible is when many individuals make independent contributions, which are then algorithmically combined (e.g., in prediction markets). However, in many cases of complex production contributors cannot be independent, but must coordinate their work. For example, a successful encyclopedia should produce articles that are complete, accurate, coherent and readable. Wikipedia editors, for example, must have a common view of what material should be included or excluded, present material with a logical flow, and produce sentences and paragraphs that are cohesive and flow together.

Our research examines how online production communities coordinate the efforts of their contributors and the conditions under which different coordination strategies are successful. The project consists of two major types of research. We conducted quantitative empirical analyzes in Wikipedia, Wikia and MathOverflow, cataloging the coordination methods these organizations use and their impact. We also conducted random-assignment experiments in Wikipedia and Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, to rigorously test when various methods are successful.

For example, we conducted a series of studies in Wikipedia to examine how leadership works. One challenge many online communities face is getting volunteers to work on tasks that are important to the organization but not necessarily to the individual volunteers. Unlike traditional organizations which can use hierarchical control (e.g., managers directing subordinates’ work), online communities must find other ways to organize coordinate action among their volunteers. We found that in Wikipedia this was accomplished through shared leadership, in which fellow volunteers directly influence each other through communication. While more formal leaders (e.g., administrators) communicate more and are more influential than regular Wikipedians, since there are so few of them compared to the tens of thousands of regular Wikipedians the end result is that most of the influence exchanges in Wikipedia (over two-thirds) occur among peers. We suggest that these influence exchanges together act as a form of shared leadership, causing Wikipedia editors to increase their contributions and work on tasks they otherwise would not have worked on. We found converging evidence for this hypothesis through mining millions of messages on Wikipedia, as well as conducting a controlled field study in which we had confederates (other Wikipedia editors) send messages of different types to people who had just created an article, and observed the effects of those messages on the recipients’ behavior.
